chapter.htmlHeader: When should I aspirate olecranon bursitis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• If septic bursitis is suspected from the clinical features or to rule out infection in persistent cases of aseptic bursitis, aspirate bursal fluid using a sterile aspiration technique (if the expertise and equipment are available) for analysis of bursal fluid. An aseptic technique provides a sample for microscopy and aspiration may also provide pain relief by reducing bursal pressure. This should ideally be done before antibiotics are started. The appearance of the fluid may give a clue as to the nature of the bursitis, but is not specific or always indicative.
    • If pus is aspirated — septic bursitis is likely (but many septic fluids are only slightly turbid in appearance, and other inflammatory non-infective conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis may also produce pus).
    • If straw-coloured fluid is aspirated — non-septic bursitis is more likely.
    • If blood-stained fluid is aspirated — septic bursitis, trauma, gout, or rheumatoid arthritis are all possible.
    • If milky fluid is aspirated — tophaceous gout or pseudogout is likely; rheumatoid arthritis is a rarer cause of milky fluid aspirate.
  • Send bursal fluid (in a sterile container) to the laboratory for Gram staining, culture, and crystal examination to provide a more definitive diagnosis. Consider requesting a differential white cell count and glucose levels for the bursal fluid, as these may help with the diagnosis especially in the absence of positive Gram stain or culture.
    • Start antibiotics if there is a high index of suspicion of septic bursitis and if necessary, switch antibiotic treatment once the bacterial sensitivities have been received.
    • The presence of urate crystals will provide a definitive diagnosis of gout, but sepsis and gout can coexist.
  • Advise the person to seek urgent medical advice if they develop signs of infection, such as fever or local cellulitis.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
When to aspirate

  • The information on when to aspirate in suspected olecranon bursitis is based on expert opinion in a consensus guideline on elbow disorders from the American College of Occupational and Environmental Medicine (ACOEM) [Hegmann, 2013], a chapter from a text book on the diagnosis and management of olecranon bursitis [Cassidy and Shubert, 2014], review articles on the diagnosis and management of olecranon bursitis [Aaron et al, 2011; Blackwell et al, 2014; Sayegh and Strauch, 2014; Reilly and Kamineni, 2016], and the British Medical Journal Best practice review on bursitis [BMJ Best Practice, 2016].
    • The treatment of septic bursitis requires needle aspiration for diagnosis and can guide antibiotic treatment once cultures are known [Sayegh and Strauch, 2014].
    • Although needle aspiration of the bursa is commonly performed for suspected septic olecranon bursitis and may be used as a definitive diagnostic test to differentiate septic from non-septic bursitis, it is not known whether the benefits of aspiration outweigh the possible drawbacks in the setting of non-septic bursitis, including the potential for introduction or local dissemination of bacteria, and the formation of sinus tracts that may cause chronic symptoms. Therefore, aspiration and analysis of the bursal fluid is recommended in cases of persistent non-septic bursitis to rule out infection [Aaron et al, 2011; Sayegh and Strauch, 2014]. 

Investigating the aspirate

  • The recommendation to request Gram staining, culture, and crystal examination is based on expert opinion in a consensus guideline on elbow disorders from the American College of Occupational and Environmental Medicine (ACOEM) [Hegmann, 2013], and review articles on the diagnosis and management of olecranon bursitis [Stell, 1996; Blackwell et al, 2014; Sayegh and Strauch, 2014; Reilly and Kamineni, 2016]. 
    • Although a differential white cell count and glucose levels for bursal fluid may be useful predictors of infection, values vary in septic and non-septic bursitis and the ranges may overlap. A relatively low leucocyte count in bursal fluid does not rule out infection and similarly a relatively high leucocyte count is non-diagnostic when used alone [Zimmermann et al, 1995; Blackwell et al, 2014; Reilly and Kamineni, 2016]. These measurements must be interpreted cautiously and as there is no overall consensus in the current literature, CKS only recommends considering a request for white cell count and bursal fluid glucose level to assist in the diagnosis of septic olecraon bursitis where appropriate.
  • The information on using fluid appearance as a guide for diagnosis is based on expert opinion in review articles [Zimmermann et al, 1995; Stell, 1996] and previous expert reviewers of this CKS topic.

Advice

  • The advice to the person following aspiration of a bursa is based on the opinion of previous expert reviewers of this CKS topic and what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
